1108038294221348865.text: Bug bounties in the traditional security space are well studied. Bug hunter effectiveness is Pareto distributed; a tiny fraction of hunters claim the vast majority of bounties. They do so by spending the least amount of time on the most lucrative bugs.https://blog.trailofbits.com/2019/01/14/on-bounties-and-boffins/ …

1108007904358076417.text: While promoting increased scrutiny of EIPs is laudable, I question the incentives created by an exponential decay. Bug hunters will likely stop once the bounty price starts falling, focusing their attention on a newer target with a fresh bounty or guaranteed assessment payout.https://twitter.com/owocki/status/1107999544212520961 …

1085390075804954627.text:
This is important in that you, & the other few who are very successful, are not representative of the norm in bug bounty skill or success.
It's misleading to tout huge numbers on platforms w out explaining that only a fraction of that number can earn a living or even find bugs.

1085389381416964098.text: You're right about yourself, your own experiences. The point of the paper, & I think ToB's review of it, is to show what the labor market looks like overall. Nobody is comparing you to anyone else. You're another data point in the set, an exceptional one, but that's it.

1085382511784611840.text:
This was not a 3rd party study using an incomplete data set.
Marketing reports by H1 are clever in hiding real numbers, instead using percentages.
Real question currently unanswered:
How many (real number) of the "300,000 hackers" have *ever* submitted a bug? Let alone been paid?

1085381085460975616.text:
This Trail of Bits blog was a review of a paper I coauthored with MIT Sloan school & Harvard researchers.
It was published in Oct 2017 as a book chapter, but work was done in 2014/15.
We used 100% complete data including private programs from H1 at the time & Facebook's programs.
